File.Title: Secondary Vestibular Cholinergic Projection to the Cerebellum of Rabbit and Rat as Revealed by Choline Acetyltransferase Immunohistochemistry, Retrograde and Orthograde Tracers
File.Authors: N.H. BARMACK, R.W. BAUGHMAN, F.P. ECKENSTEIN, AND H. SHOJAKU

Abstract.S: Previously we have shown that four regions of the cerebellum, the uvula-nodulus, flocculus, ventral paraflocculus, and anterior lobe 1, receive extensive, but not exclusive, cholinergic mossy fiber projections.

In the present experiment we have studied the origin of three of these projections in the rat and rabbit (uvula-nodulus, flocculus, ventral paraflocculus), using choline acetyltransferase (ChAT) immunohistochemistry in combination with a double label, retrogradely transported horseradish peroxidase (HRP).
We have demonstrated that in both the rat and rabbit the caudal medial vestibular nucleus (MVN) and to a lesser extent the nucleus prepositus hypoglossus (NPH) contain ChAT-positive neurons.
Neurons of the caudal MVN are double-labeled following HRP injections into the uvula-nodulus.
HRP injections into the uvula-nodulus also labeled less than 5% of the neurons in the cholinergic vestibular efferent complex.
Fewer CUT-positive neurons in the MVN and some CUT-positive neurons in the NPH are double-labeled following HRP injections into the flocculus.
Almost no ChAT-positive neurons in the MVN and some ChAT-positive neurons in the NPH are double-labeled following HRP injections into the ventral paraflocculus.

Injections of Phaseolus leucougglutinin (PHA-L) into the caudal MVN of both the rat and rabbit demonstrated projection patterns to the uvula-nodulus and flocculus that were qualitatively similar to those observed using ChAT immunohistochemistry.

We conclude that the cholinergic mossy fiber pathway to the cerebellum in general and the uvula-nodulus in particular is likely to mediate secondary vestibular information related to postural adjustments.

Introduction.S: Previously, using immunohistochemical stains for choline acetyltransferase (CUT), we have demonstrated a cholinergic mossy fiber projection concentrated, but not restricted to four regions of the cerebellum of the rat, rabbit, cat, and monkey.

In particular we demonstrated that CUTimmunoreactive mossy fibers with classical rosette morphology, as well as finely beaded (varicose) ChAT-positive fibers project to the granule cell layer and invade the molecular layer of the uvula-nodulus, the flocculus, the ventral paraflocculus and anterior lobes 1-2 (Barmack et al., '92).

The regional inhomogeneities with respect to the distribution of cholinergic mossy fiber pathways prompts the question concerning the origin(s) of the pathways to the regions of the cerebellum with the greatest cholinergic innervation.

Classical silver degeneration studies have identified secondary vestibular projections to at the flocculus and uvulanodulus, regions that receive cholinergic projections (Dow, '36; Brodal and Hoivik, '64; Larsell, '70).

More recent retrograde tracer experiments have demonstrated projections to the uvula-nodulus, flocculus, and anterior lobules 1 and 2 from the vestibular nuclei (Kotchabhakdi and Walberg, '78a; Yamamoto, '79; Matsushita and Okado, '81; Hirai, '83; Blanks et al., '83; Sat0 et al., '83; Brodal and Brodal, '85; Magras and Voogd, '85; Langer et al., '85; Epema et al., '85; Walberg and Dietrichs, '88).

Although, there is a primary vestibular afferent projection to the nodulus and uvula, with weaker primary afferent projections to the flocculus and anterior lobe (Brodal and Hoivik, '64; Carpenter et al., '72; Kotchabhakdi and Walberg, '78b; Korte and Mugnaini, '79; Carleton and Carpenter, '84; Gerrits et al., '89) we have found no ChAT-immunoreactive staining in vestibular primary afferent cell bodies in Scarpa's ganglion of either rabbits or cats (Barmack, Baughman and Shojaku, unpublished observations).

In view of these anatomical findings, the present experiment was undertaken to examine the possible origin of the cholinergic mossy fiber projections to the cerebellum from secondary vestibular neurons in both the rat and rabbit.
First, we have used an immunohistochemical stain for ChAT to examine cholinergic neurons in the vestibular complex.

Second, after pressure injecting small quantities of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) into different cerebellar regions, we have examined the brainstem for the distribution of neurons that were retrogradely labeled with HRP and that were identified as cholinergic by ChAT immunohistochemistry.

Finally, we have iontophoretically injected Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHA-L) into the caudal aspect of the medial vestibular nucleus to determine if the orthogradely labeled secondary vestibular projection to the cerebellum conforms to the distribution of secondary vestibular cholinergic afferents.
We have found that the cholinergic projection to the uvula and nodulus of both the rat and rabbit originates from the medial vestibular complex.
This projection also includes some afferents that originate from the nucleus prepositus hypoglossi.
A smaller cholinergic projection to the fiocculus also originates in part from the caudal medial vestibular nucleus and the nucleus prepositus hypoglossi.
A smaller projection to the ventral paraflocculus originates from the caudal nucleus prepositus hypoglossi.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS

The brains from a total of 11 rats and 22 rabbits were prepared for either HRP retrograde transport studies combined with C U T immunocytochemistry, or for the study of vestibulocerebellar projection patterns as indicated by the orthograde transport of Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHA-L).
Retrograde tracer: HRP

Non-albino rabbits weighing 1.0-1.4 kg, and SpragueDawley rats weighing 0.3-0.6 kg were anesthetized with intramuscular injections of ketamine hydrochloride (50 mg/kg), xylazine (6 mg/kg), and acepromazine maleate (1.2 mg/kg).

The caudal cerebellum was exposed and a 30% solution of HRP or a 3% solution of wheat germ agglutinin (WGA)-HRP was pressure injected through a glass micropipette connected to a 1 ~1 syringe (Hamilton).
For uvulanodulus injections, the micropipette was inserted through the dorsal uvula into the ventral aspect of the uvula and into the nodulus at several medial-lateral locations.
A total of 0.5-2.5 ~1 was pressure injected.

For injections into the flocculus and ventral paraflocculus, the middle ear was surgically exposed and a 1 mm opening was made just rostra1 to the lateral aspect of the anterior semicircular canal (Barmack and Pettorossi, '85).
The micropipette was inserted rostrally through this opening to inject HRP into the flocculus and ventrally and caudally through the opening to inject HRP into the ventral paraflocculus.
Following a 2-3 day postoperative survival, animals were deeply anesthetized with sodium pentobarbital (60 mg/kg).

They were subsequently perfused transcardially with 0.9% saline, followed by a 2.0-2.5% paraformaldehyde, 0.15% picric acid, and 0.05-0.20% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M sodium phosphate (PBS), pH = 7.2, lasting 20-30 minutes.
The perfusion was terminated with a rinse of 0.1 M PBS, pH = 7.4.
The brains were removed and dehydrated with lo%, 20%, and 30% sucrose in 0.1 M PBS, pH = 7.4.
The brainstem and cerebellum were cut into blocks, mounted onto cork with OCT compound, and frozen in isopentane cooled with liquid nitrogen.
Frozen sections (30-40 pm) were cut and collected in cold 0.1 M PBS, pH = 7.4.
The sections were kept in separate compartments of a small plastic grid that had 42 separate compartments with a floor of nylon mesh.

A DAB-stabilized, CoC1,-intensified (Rye et al., '841, tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) reaction (Olucha et al., '85) was used to demonstrate the presence of retrogradely transported HRP as a granular black reaction product prior to processing the tissue for ChAT immunohistochemistry .
Choline acetyltransferase (ChAT) immunohistochemistry
Two different polyclonal antibodies to ChAT were used: 1) rat-apig-ChAT, a rat antiserum to pig CUT, and 2) mouse-arat-ChAT, a mouse antiserum to rat ChAT.
These antibodies were prepared and characterized as described previously (Eckenstein et al., '81).
Orthograde tracer: PHA-L

Non-albino rabbits weighing 1.0-1.4 kg, and Sprague Dawley rats weighing 0.3-0.6 kg were anesthetized with intramuscular injections of ketamine hydrochloride (50 mg/kg), xylazine (6 mg/kg), and acepromazine maleate (1.2 mg/kg).

The brainstems of rabbits and rats were exposed through the cisterna magna, and a micropipette containing a solution of 2.5% PHA-L in 0.1 M PBS, pH = 7.4, was inserted under direct vision into the medial vestibular nucleus (MVN) (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84; Ter Horst et al., '84).
The PHA-L was iontophoretically injected into the MVN, using 10 FA cathodal pulses lasting 10 seconds, with a 50% duty cycle.
Several (3-5) injections were made along the medial-lateral and rostral-caudal extent of the MVN.
Each injection lasted 10 minutes.
After a 6-10 day survival period, the animals were anesthetized with sodium pentobarbital and transcardially perfused.
A brief saline flush was followed by a 4% paraformaldehyde, 0.15% picric acid solution in 0.1 M PBS, pH = 7.2.
The perfusion was terminated with a .1 M PBS, pH = 7.4.
The brains were removed and dehydrated with lo%, 20%, and 30% sucrose in .1 M PBS, pH = 7.4.
The brainstems and cerebella were cut into blocks, mounted onto cork with OCT compound, and frozen in isopentane cooled with liquid nitrogen.
Frozen sections (30-40 pm) were cut and collected in cold. 1 M PBS, pH = 7.4, into a small plastic grid divided into 42 separate compartments that had a floor of nylon mesh.
A double PAP immunohistochemical procedure, with DAB as the reaction product, was used to identify the presence of orthogradely transported PHA-L.

Results.S: RESULTS
immunoreactivity in the vestibular nuclei of the rat
The brainstems of 4 rats were examined in both cross section and sagittal section for ChAT-like immunoreactivity.

secondary vestibular neurons were labeled in two main clusters within a rostral - caudal axis of the vestibular complex extending from a caudal level of the dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus ( nx ) to a rostral level of the abducens nucleus ( figs . 1 , 2 ) .
labeled neurons were found in the most caudal aspect of the medial vestibular nucleus ( mvn ) extending into the nucleus prepositus hypoglossi ( nph ) .
many smaller spindle - shaped neurons with cell body diameters of less than 8 frn were observed in both the caudal and rostral mvn near the ventricular surface ( fig . lb , c ) .
these spindle shaped neurons were particularly evident in sagittal sections ( fig . 2b , c ) .
Larger ChAT-positive multipolar neurons with cell bodies exceeding 10 pm were located nearer the middle and ventral aspects of the MVN and the NPH.
chat - like immunoreactivity in the vestibular nuclei of the rabbit
The brainstems of 5 rabbits were examined with ChAT immunohistochemistry.
the distribution of chat - positive neurons within the vestibular complex of the rabbit was more restricted than in the rat .

labeled neurons were found primarily in the caudal third of the medial vestibular nucleus , extending from the level of the dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus to about 1 mm more rostral ( fig . 3 , 4 ) .
the more rostral mvn , at the level of the facial genu and abducens nucleus was almost devoid of labeled neurons .
ChAT-positive neurons extended from the ventricular surface of the MVN to its deepest aspect approximately 500-700 pm below the surface.
fewer cut - positive neurons were observed in the nph .
examples of cutand hrp - labeled neurons in the vestibular complex following pressure injections of hrp into the cerebellum of the rat and rabbit
hrp injections were made in the uvula - nodulus , flocculus , and ventral paraflocculus of 14 rabbits , and in the uvula - nodulus of 4 rats .

appropriate adjustments were made in the chat immunohistochemical protocol to obtain good immunohistochemical staining for chat as well as adequate sensitivity to the reaction product for retrogradely transported hrp .

using dab as the substrate , the reaction product for c u t immunohistochemistry had a translucent brown appearance , whereas the coc1 , - intensified , dab stabilized tmb reaction product for retrogradely transported hrp had a granular black appearance .

optimal double label results were obtained when the reaction product from one stain ( either the chat or retrograde hrp ) was not so intense that it could obscure the reaction product from the other stain .
examples of double labeled neurons in the vestibular nuclear complex following cerebellar hrp injections are illustrated in figure 5 .
figure 5a - c illustrate neurons located within the a following an hrp injection into the rat uvula - nodulus ( see fig . 6 for an illustration of the injection site ) .
the solid arrows indicate mvn neurons that clearly contained reaction product for both chat and hrp .

the open arrow ( fig . 5a ) indicates a neuron that was so densely labeled with hrp reaction product that the chat reaction product that it was impossible to determine if chat reaction product was also present .
the asterisk ( fig . 5c ) is an example of an hrp - filled neuron without any chat reaction product .
in the rabbit , an hrp injection into the ventral paraflocculus labeled neurons in the nph ( fig . 5d ) .
the actual hrp injection site is illustrated in figure 9a .
the open arrows again indicate two neurons that were so densely labeled with hrp reaction product that it was not possible to determine if they were also cut - positive .
The solid arrow in Figure 5D indicates a neuron that was clearly double-labeled.
figure 5e indicates a double - labeled neuron from the mvn of a rabbit following an hrp injection into the uvula - nodulus ( see fig . 7 for an illustration of the injection site ) .

because of the difficulties in unambiguously identifying double - labeled neurons and because hrp injections into different regions of the cerebellum were always subtotal , it is likely that our counts of double - labeled neurons underestimates the true number cholinergic neurons with specific cerebellar projections .
chatand hrp - labeled neurons in the vestibular complex following pressure injections of hrp into the uvula - nodulus of the rat
pressure injections of hrp into the uvula - nodulus were made in 4 rats .
these injections caused retrograde transport of hrp into chat - labeled neurons in the dvn and nph , but the mvn contained the largest number of double - labeled neurons .
these double - labeled neurons were concentrated in the caudal half of the mvn , but could be observed as far rostrally as the abducens nucleus .
the mvn , svn , dvn , and nph also contained neurons that were clearly singly labeled for either hrp or cut ( fig . 6 ) .
figure 6a illustrates the largest extent of diffusion of hrp at the injection site .
Only the brainstem ipsilateral to the intended injection is illustrated.
The projection pattern of secondary vestibular neurons is bilateral.
although our intention was to make unilateral hrp injections into the uvula - nodulus , the actual injection sites could not be confined to just one side of this vermal structure .

hence , a comparison of relative numbers of ipsilateral and contralatera1 brainstem neurons that were double - labeled following uvula - nodulus injections in either the rat or rabbit would be meaningless .
cutand hrp - labeled neurons in the
vestibular complex following pressure injections of hrp into the uvula - nodulus of the rabbit
pressure injections of hrp into the uvula - nodulus were made in 8 rabbits .
these injections caused retrograde transport of hrp into cut - labeled neurons located primarily in the caudal mvn ( fig . 7 ) .
in contrast to results obtained in the rat , there were few cut - labeled neurons and no double - labeled neurons located in the rostral mvn .
a few neurons in the caudal nph and dvn were labeled for both cut and hrp following hrp injections into the rabbit uvula - nodulus .
cutand hrp - labeled neurons in the
vestibular complex following pressure injections of hrp into the flocculus of the rabbit
in 3 rabbits pressure injections of hrp were made directly into the flocculus .

by approaching the flocculus through the middle ear ( see materials and methods ) it was possible to make hrp injections directly into the flocculus without also injecting other cerebellar lobules ( fig . 8 ) .
following hrp injections into the flocculus neurons in the mvn , dvn , nph , and nucleus x were labeled bilaterally .
however , fewer of these hrp - labeled neurons were found in the caudal mvn where chat - labeled neurons were most densely concentrated .
many more hrp - labeled neurons were cut - negative and were located in the rostral half of the mvn .
the greatest number of chatand hrp - labeled neurons was located in the nph ( fig . 8b ) .
chatand hrp - labeled neurons in the vestibular complex following pressure injections of hrp into the ventral paraflocculus of the rabbit
in the rabbit , the ventral paraflocculus receives a very prominent cholinergic input .
the four lobules that comprise the ventral paraflocculus in the rabbit have the highest levels of chat activity of any lobules in the cerebellum ( barmack et al . , ' 92 ) .
in three rabbits , pressure injections of hrp were made directly into the ventral paraflocculus through a middle ear approach ( see materials and methods ) ( fig . 9 ) .
few neurons were double - labeled in any part of the vestibular nuclear complex following ventral parafloccular injections with the exception of the nph .
the caudal aspect of the nph contained a bilaterally symmetric number of hrpand cut - labeled neurons ( fig . 9 ) .
cutand hrp - labeled neurons in the lateral
reticular nucleus following injections of hrp into the uvula - nodulus , flocculus and ventral paraflocculus of the rat and rabbit
the lateral reticular nucleus is a source of mossy fibers to the cerebellum ( kunzle , ' 75 ) .
in agreement with previous investigations , we observed chat - labeled neurons within the lateral reticular nucleus ( lrn ) ( tago et al . , ' 89 azizi et al . , ' 90 ) .
however , following hrp injections into the uvulanodulus of either the rat or the rabbit few double labeled neurons were observed in the lrn .
figure 10 demonstrates one double labeled neuron in the lrn of a rat following a uvula - nodulus injection .
we observed no double - labeled neurons in the lrn of the rabbit following hrp injections into the nodulus of the rabbit .

although we observed both chat - labeled and hrp - labeled neurons in the lrn following injections of hrp into the flocculus or ventral paraflocculus , we obsewed no unequvivocally double - labeled neurons .

this lack of double labeling could not be attributed to poor retrograde transport of hrp since appropriate groups of neurons in the vestibular complex and inferior olive were well - labeled following cerebellar hrp injections .
cutand hrp - labeled neurons in the
vestibular efferent nucleus following pressure injections of hrp into the uvula - nodulus of the rat and rabbit
The major cluster of neurons that comprise the vestibular efferent complex of both the rabbit and the rat is located just above and lateral to the genu of the facial nerve.
in the rabbit , neurons of this complex have been identified by retrograde transport of hrp injected into the perilymphatic space through the oval window ( barmack , ' 90 ) .
Neurons within this nuclear complex are CUT-positive (Barmack, '90).

this vestibular efferent complex has also been identified previously as the paragenual nucleus in the rat ( paxinos and watson , ' 86 tag0 et al . , ' 89 ) and nucleus supragenualis in the rabbit ( meessen and olszewski , ' 49 ) .

it was somewhat surprising for us to note , following pressure injections of hrp into the uvula - nodulus of the rat and rabbit , that approximately 5% of the neurons in the vestibular efferent complex were double - labeled ( fig . 11 ) .
in one rat ( rat 63 ) , the vestibular efferent complex contained 183 neurons ipsilateral to an hrp injection located primarily in the right uvula - nodulus .
Ten of these neurons were double labeled.
eight out of 186 neurons in the left vestibular efferent complex were also double labeled .
such double - labeled neurons were not observed following hrp injections into either the flocculus or the ventral paraflocculus .
The possible causes of these double-labeled neurons will be considered in the Discussion.
other cholinergic nuclei that were not double - labeled following pressure injections of hrp into the uvula , nodulus , flocculus , and ventral paraflocculus of the rat or rabbit
Several brainstem nuclei containing ChAT-positive neurons might be suspected as possible sources of cerebellar cholinergic afferents.
these nuclei include cranial nerve nuclei 3 , 4 , 5 , 6 , 7 , 10 , 12 edinger westphal nucleus and the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus .
each of these nuclei in both the rat and rabbit contained chat - positive neurons , but none of these neurons were labeled retrogradely by hrp in the present experiment .
VII
projection from the vestibular complex to the uvula - nodulus of the rat as determined with the use of pha - l
iontophoretic injections ( see materials and methods ) of pha - l were made into the vestibular complex of 3 rats under direct vision .
the pha - l injections filled the caudal half of the mvn , but also included parts of the nph and dvn ( fig . 12a ) .
these injections orthogradely labeled a mossy fiber projection to the uvula - nodulus of the cerebellum .

the distribution of this mossy fiber projection included the entire nodulus and the ventral layer of the uvula , corresponding to the distribution of the cholinergic mossy fiber pathway to this region ( see fig . 1 barmack et al . , ' 91 ) .
a few labeled mossy fiber terminals were also observed in the flocculus ( fig . 12e ) and lobule 1 of the anterior lobe ( not illustrated ) .
this same injection site also projected to the p nucleus and dorsal cap of the inferior olive ( fig . 12f ) .
A vestibulo-olivary pathway has been demonstrated previously to be GABAergic (Nelson et al., '86, '89).
several different kinds of mossy fiber terminals were labeled within the uvula - nodulus .
Single mossy fiber afferents were observed that serially gave rise to synaptic rosettes at intervals of 140-170 pm.

we also observed fine varicose fibers that were continuous with large mossy fiber rosettes in the granule cell layer and that penetrated past the purkinje cell layer into the molecular layer in both the nodulus ( fig . 12d ) and the flocculus ( fig . 12e ) .
projection from the vestibular complex to the uvula - nodulus of the rabbit as determined with the use of pha - l
iontophoretic injections of pha - l into the mvn of the rabbit produced mossy fiber labeling with a terminal distribution in the cerebellum similar to that observed in the rat .
lobules 9d and 10 received a densely labeled mossy fiber projection ( fig . 13b , e ) .
labeled mossy fibers also terminated in the granule cell layer of the flocculus ( fig . 13d ) .
some of these mossy fiber rosettes gave rise to fine beaded ( varicose ) fibers that terminated in the molecular layer ( fig . 13d ) .
labeled mossy fibers were also observed in lobule 1 of the anterior lobe .
few labeled mossy fibers terminated in the ventral paraflocculus .
in addition to these expected termination sites , other terminal regions were observed .

these regions were located at the base of four major cerebellar fissures the primary fissure , the fissure between lobules 1 and 2 , the fissure between lobules 2 and 3 and the fissure between lobules 3 and 4 ( fig . 14 ) .

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
cholinergic component of the secondary afferent vestibular projection to the cerebellum
The present experiment has identified regions of the vestibular complex in the rat and rabbit that contain cholinergic neurons as identified by CUT immunohistochemistry.

Furthermore it has been shown that many of these neurons, particularly those in the caudal medial vestibular nucleus are filled retrogradely by HRP following pressure injections of HRP into the regions of the cerebellum in which we previously identified higher concentrations of cholinergic mossy fiber terminals.

The observation that the caudal medial vestibular nucleus of the rabbit and rat contains a subpopulation of cholinergic neurons that project to the cerebellum contradicts some earlier surveys based upon ChAT immunohistochemistry that used different antibodies to ChAT and different protocols (Armstrong et al., '83; Carpenter et al., '87).
These investigations failed to find a significant population of cholinergic neurons in the vestibular complex of the 2 rnrn
2 mm
rat, although cholinergic neurons were found in the caudal MVN of the monkey (Carpenter et al., '87).
More recently, other immunohistochemical surveys have revealed ChAT positive neurons in the caudal MVN of the rat (Tago et al., '89).
These positive findings are consistent with radiochemical measurements of ChAT activity in tissue samples obtained from the vestibular nuclei using the "micropunch" technique (Burke and Fahn, '85).
The ChAT activity of the MVN was higher by at least a factor of 10 than was the ChAT activity of the SVN, DVN, or LVN.
These data were interpreted to indicate the presence of a cholinergic projection to the MVN rather than the existence of cholinergic neurons within the MVN (Burke and Fahn, '85).
There is preliminary electrophysiological evidence from MVN slice recordings that suggests that MVN neurons may have muscarinic, but not nicotinic receptors (Ujihara et al., '88, '89).
So it is possible that both cholinergic axon terminals and cholinergic cell bodies account for the relatively high levels of ChAT activity in the MVN.
Some of the ChAT containing axons in the MVN may be collaterals of ChAT containing neurons that project to the cerebellum.
Cholinergic projections to the flocculus and ventral paraflocculus in the rabbit
Previously we have demonstrated a modest cholinergic projection to the flocculus of the rabbit using immunohistochemistry and a regional assay for ChAT activity (Barmack et d., '92).
In the present investigation we have demonstrated that at least part of this projection originates in the caudal medial vestibular nucleus and the nucleus prepositus hypoglossi.

In the rabbit, the ventral paraflocculus receives the largest cholinergic projection, measured either immunohistochemically or by the ChAT activity assay, However, there is discrepancy between the extent of this cholinergic projection to the ventral paraflocculus of the rabbit and the relatively meager number of double labeled neurons found in either the medial vestibular nucleus or the nucleus prepositus hypoglossi following HRP injections into the ventral paraflocculus.
Furthermore, no other nuclear groups of cholinergic neurons within the brainstem were double labeled following HRP injections into the ventral paraflocculus of the rabbit.

This means that 1) the few cholinergic neurons that do project to the ventral paraflocculus must branch extensively within the ventral paraflocculus, or 2) we have missed a more distributed origin of cholinergic fibers, or 3) both our immunohistochemical and ChAT activity measurements are in error.
We think that the third possibility is unlikely.
Cholinergic receptors in the cerebellar cortex
The localization of a major cholinergic input to the uvula-nodulus is consistent with receptor binding studies that have provided pharmacological evidence for both nicotinic and muscarinic receptors.
In rat cerebellar tissue slices, the nicotinic agonist, [3H]methylcarbamylcholine (MCC), binds to a single class of high-affinity binding sites (Lapchak et al., '89).

The nicotinic antagonist 1251-abungarotoxin binds to sites within the granule cell layer of the uvula-nodulus, the region that receives the largest cholinergic mossy fiber projection (Hunt and Schmidt, '78).

Pharmacological-histochemical evidence suggests a wide spread distribution of muscarinic receptors in the cerebellum, but with greater concentrations in the uvula-nodulus (Rotter et al., '79; Ravikumar and Sastry, '85; Neustadt et al., '88).
The muscarinic antagonists, propylbenzilycholine mustard and ['H]quinuclidinyl benzilate, bind to both the molecular and granule cell layers.
The apparent species differences with regard to the laminar distribution of u 1 mm
cerebellar muscarinic receptor sites may be related to the relative numbers of fine varicose cholinergic fibers that penetrate into the molecular layer.

Such fine varicose fibers were observed only infrequently following PHA-L injections into the MVN in the present experiment, but this might be attributed to the failure of PHA-L to diffuse into the fine mossy fiber terminal fibers.

The localization of the principle targets of cholinergic mossy fibers to the granule cell layer of the cerebellum is supported by biochemical studies of isolated cerebellar glomeruli that have demonstrated a high-affinity choline uptake system (Balazs et al., 75; Terrian et al., 86).
At present nothing is known concerning possible regional differences in this high-affinity choline uptake system.
Vestibular efferent projection to the uvula-nodulus?

One of the surprising findings of the present experiment was the observation that some of the neurons of the cholinergic vestibular efferent complex were labeled with HRP following pressure injections of HRP into the uvulanodulus.
Such labeling was not observed following injections into either the flocculus or the ventral paraflocculus.
Unlike the flocculus or the paraflocculus, the uvulanodulus receives a large primary vestibular afferent projection.

We have observed that 60-70% of the neurons in Scarpa s ganglion are labeled retrogradely following HRP injections into the uvula-nodulus, whereas only 2% of these ganglion cells are labeled after HRP injections into the flocculus (Barmack et al., 86).
It is possible that some of the vestibular efferent neurons project to the uvula-nodulus.
However, it seems more likely, that the labeling of vestibular efferent neurons was a secondary consequence of the large primary afferent projection to this region.
We suppose that HRP was taken up by vestibular primary afferent terminals in the cerebellar cortex and retrogradely transported to the peripheral vestibular apparatus.
In the peripheral vestibular apparatus some HRP could have been released by primary vestibular afferent dendritic endings that are in close proximity to vestibular efferent endings.
The HRP could have been taken up by vestibular efferent terminals and retrogradely transported back into the cell bodies of the vestibular efferent complex.
Functional role of the cholinergic cerebellum in motor control

In a previous study we identified four cerebellar regions that received cholinergic mossy fibers-the uvula-nodulus, flocculus, ventral paraflocculus, and lobule 1 of the anterior lobe vermis (Barmack et al., 91).

In the present experiment we have shown that at least a fraction of the mossy fiber input to these regions (uvula-nodulus, flocculus, ventral paraflocculus) originates from CUT-positive neurons in the caudal MVN or NPH.

We have not studied the projections to lobule 1 of the anterior lobe, but it seems likely, based on both anatomical and electrophysiological studies that this region also receives a cholinergic input that originates, in part, from the vestibular complex (Matsushita and Okado, 81; Hirai, 83).
The major second order vestibular projection to the uvula-nodulus originates from the caudal half of the caudal MVN.
In the both the cat and the rabbit, the uvula-nodulus also sends reciprocal projections to the caudal MVN (Shojaku et al., 87; Walberg and Dietrichs, 88).
In the cat, the rostral and lateral regions of the MVN receive projections from the flocculus (Angaut and Brodd, 67).

In addition to the cholinergic secondary afferent vestibular projection to the uvula-nodulus, this structure also receives a major primary afferent projection (Korte and Mugnaini, 79; Barmack et al., 86; Gerrits et al., 89).
This primary afferent projection is not cholinergic as demonstrated by the lack of CUT-positive immunoreactivity of Scarpa s ganglion (Barmack, Baughman and Shojaku, unpublished observations).

Electrical stimulation of the uvula-nodulus only weakly inhibits vestibuloocular activity, but strongly inhibits vestibular neurons that transmit vestibular and spinal signals to the cerebellar nuclei and cerebellar cortex (Precht et al., 76).

Lesions of the uvula-nodulus in cats (Fernandez and Fredrickson, 64) or dogs (Singleton, 67) prolongs the duration of nystagmic eye movements induced by either natural vestibular stimulation or by caloric stimulation.
Adaptive modification of eye movements evoked by optokinetic stimulation is also impaired following lesions of the uvula-nodulus in cats (Mason and Baker, 89).
In monkeys, uvula-nodulus lesions cause a similar loss of ability to habituate to a vestibularly-induced nystagmus (Waespe et al., 85).
Uvula-nodulus lesions in monkeys also cause a decrease in slow phase velocity of optokinetically-evoked nystagmus (Igarashi et al., 83).

Microelectrode recordings from the uvula-nodulus demonstrate that the uvula-nodulus receives both mossy fiber and climbing fiber inputs that convey information from the vertical semicircular canals as well as utricular otolith (Ferin et al., 71; Marini et al., 76; Barmack and Shojaku, 89).

Climbing fiber mediated vestibular inputs conveying both vertical semicircular canal, otolith and visual information form a topographic medio-lateral projection pattern on the surface of the uvula-nodulus (Barmack and Shojaku, 89).
The topographic distribution of these vestibularly and optokinetically evoked CFRs suggests that the climbing fiber system of the nodulus encodes a vestibular-visual space.
The medio-lateral gradient on the nodular surface encodes all degrees of vestibular inputs from backward to lateral to forward, in response to stimulation of the vestibular-optokinetic system.
This information could be used to regulate appropriate postural responses.

In addition to a possible role in regulating skeletal muscles involved in postural control, the uvula-nodulus appears to be involved in regulation of heart rate, blood pressure, vascular resistance and compensatory orthostatic reflexes (Moruzzi, 40; Rasheed et al., 70; Doba and Reis, 72; Bradley et al., 87; Henry et al., 89).
The uvula-nodulus has the appropriate anatomical connections to play an important role in the control of posture using both vestibular and visual information.

The cholinergic mossy fiber pathway described in the present experiment may be particularly important in regulating the sensitivity of the uvula-nodulus to its extraordinarily large vestibular primary afferent input.
The uvula-nodulus has been implicated in the genesis of motion sickness, since removal of the uvula-nodulus in dogs decreases the likelihood of vestibularly-induced vomiting (Money, 70).

In this regard it is of interest to recall that the most effective anti-motion sickness agents are H, receptor blockers that have antimuscarinic actions (Douglas, 85) and the belladonna alkaloids, such as scopolamine, that are also antimuscarinics (Kohl and Homick, 83; Weiner, 85).
